title:
Longtime behaviors of an epidemic model with nonlocal diffusions and a
  free boundary: spreading-vanishing dichotomy
abstract:
We propose a nonlocal epidemic model whose spatial domain evolves over time
and is represented by $[0,h(t)]$ with $h(t)$ standing for the spreading front
of epidemic. It is assumed that the agents can cross the fixed boundary $x=0$,
but they will die immediately if they do it, which implies that the area
$(-\infty,0)$ is a hostile environment for the agents. We first show that this
model is well posed, then prove that the longtime behaviors are governed by a
spreading-vanishing dichotomy and finally give some criteria determining
spreading and vanishing. Particularly, we obtain the asymptotical behaviors of
the principal eigenvalue of a cooperative system with nonlocal diffusions
without assuming the related nonlocal operator is self-adjoint, and the steady
state problem of such cooperative system on half space $[0,\infty)$ is studied
in detail.
